name: Bioconda
tagline: a distribution of bioinformatics software realized as a channel for the versatile package manager Conda
body:
[![star this repo](http://githubbadges.com/star.svg?user=bioconda&repo=recipes&style=flat&color=fff&background=0090FF)](https://github.com/bioconda/recipes/stargazers)
[![fork this repo](http://githubbadges.com/fork.svg?user=bioconda&repo=recipes&style=flat&color=fff&background=0090FF)](https://github.com/bioconda/recipes/fork)

Bioconda is a community based-effort to create a distribution of bioinformatics software realized as a channel for the versatile package manager [Conda](http://conda.pydata.org/docs).
Key features of Conda are

* very easy package creation,
* distribution of packages via channels on [Anaconda.org](https://anaconda.org),
* a command line client for simple installation and dependency handling in the spirit of ``conda install mypackage``,
* a mechanism for creating isolated environments that allows different package versions to coexist.

These features turn Conda into the perfect package manager for bioinformatics, where analyses often involve the application of various tools with sometimes complicated and even conflicting dependencies or mixtures of different languages.
Ultimately, the usage of Conda should help to perform reproducible science.

## Usage

### Step 1: Install Conda

To use bioconda, you need to install a version of Conda which is most easily obtained via the [Miniconda](http://conda.pydata.org/miniconda.html) Python distribution.

### Step 2: Explore the available packages

The list of available packages can be explored in our [bioconda channel](https://anaconda.org/bioconda).

### Step 3: Install packages or create environments

After installing Miniconda, you can use the ``conda`` command to install packages from bioconda, e.g.

```bash
conda install -c bioconda bwa
```

Isolated environments (with e.g. specific software versions) can be created via

```bash
conda create -n myenviroment -c bioconda bwa=0.7.12
```

Instead of specifying the channel manually at the command line, you can permanently subscribe by adding the following to the ``.condarc`` file in your home folder:

```yaml
channels:
    - defaults
    - bioconda
```

For more information, visit the [Conda documentation](http://conda.pydata.org/docs) or have a look at the command line options by executing

```bash
conda --help
```

### Step 4: Join the team

Because our time is limited, the policy is to add a package if we need it ourselves.
However, we invite anybody who wants to use Conda for bioinformatics to [join the team](https://github.com/bioconda/recipes/issues/1) and contribute new packages.
To get started, have a look at our [recipes](https://github.com/bioconda/recipes) and the [Conda documentation](http://conda.pydata.org/docs/building/recipe.html#conda-recipe-files-overview).
